item.title: java.util.concurrent for Distributed Coordination
item.description: I gave this talk at the following conferences: Devoxx Ukraine, November 2019 Berlin Expert Days, September 2019 Devoxx Poland, June 2019 IMC Summit Europe - London, June 2019 Riga Dev Days, May 2019 GeeCON Krakow, May 2019 JEEConf Kyiv, April 2019 Abstract The evolution of distributed coordination tools shows that high-level APIs ease implementation of coordination tasks, such as leader election, locking, synchronized actions. For instance, the Chubby paper highlights familiarity of lock-based interfaces.

item.title: Replication Distilled: Hazelcast Deep Dive
item.description: I gave this talk at the following conferences: Topconf Tallinn, November 2018 IMC Summit NA - San Francisco, October 2018 Berlin Expert Days, September 2018 JDK.IO, July 2018 Abstract Distributed data stores cope with the challenges of managing replicated data. Building a distributed data store is hard, and clarifying its high level properties is even harder. Hazelcast makes use of several replication techniques to offer choices for the trade-offs between consistency, availability, and latency properties.

item.title: Distributed Systems Theory for Mere Mortals
item.description: I gave this talk at the following conferences and meetups: Software Craftsmanship Turkey Meetup Istanbul, December 2017 Topconf Dusseldorf, October 2017 GeeCON Krakow, May 2017 Javaday Istanbul, May 2017 Goto Chicago (Sponsored), May 2017 Abstract This is a light talk about the fundamental topics of distributed systems theory. It introduces a few theoretical system models, and briefly discusses how they reflect to real world problems. It talks about the concept of time, how we perceive and use it to order things in distributed systems.
